If C\mathcal{C}C is the category of unital commutative rings, we can consider the endofunctor A↦A[X]A\mapsto A[X]A↦A[X]. It outputs the ``free AAA-algebra''.

How should I think about the interactions of this endofunctor with tensor product? Such as:

  • A[X]⊗AA[X]≅A[X,Y]A[X]\otimes_A A[X]\cong A[X,Y]A[X]⊗A​A[X]≅A[X,Y]
  • If A→ιBA\overset{\iota}{\to} BA→ιB, then A[X]/I⊗AB≅B[X]/Bι(I)A[X]/I \otimes_A B \cong B[X]/B\iota(I)A[X]/I⊗A​B≅B[X]/Bι(I).
Good question, polynomial algebras give a codifferential category. I can explain this a bit later, but maybe @JS PL (he/him) wants to do it also.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Good question, polynomial algebras give a codifferential category. I can explain this a bit later, but maybe JS PL (he/him) wants to do it also.

No that's not what @Hugo Jenkins is talking about here... This question is not related to differential categories in the way you are thinking. (While I do love differential categories, not everything can be answered by differential categories!)

But here's an attempt at an answer:
Let CRING\mathsf{CRING}CRING be the category of commutative (unital) rings. And let P:CRING→CRINGP: \mathsf{CRING} \to \mathsf{CRING}P:CRING→CRING be the functor which maps P(A)=A[X]P(A) = A[X]P(A)=A[X].
Alternatively, we may write this as P(A)=A⊗Z[X]P(A) = A \otimes \mathbb{Z}[X]P(A)=A⊗Z[X] -- where the tensor product of Z\mathbb{Z}Z-modules, which is the coproduct in CRING\mathsf{CRING}CRING
It's neat to note that PPP is both a monad and comonad

I guess the multiplication PP⇒PPP \Rightarrow PPP⇒P gives the ring homomorphism A[X1,X2]→A[X]A[X_1,X_2] \to A[X]A[X1​,X2​]→A[X] sending both X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​ to XXX. What does the comultiplication do? Send XXX to X1+X2X_1 + X_2X1​+X2​?

(In other notation X1+X2X_1 + X_2X1​+X2​ is X⊗1+1⊗X∈A[X]⊗AA[X]X \otimes 1 + 1 \otimes X \in A[X] \otimes_A A[X]X⊗1+1⊗X∈A[X]⊗A​A[X], which is a respectable-looking thing for a comultiplication to do.)

John Baez said:

What does the comultiplication do? Send XXX to X1+X2X_1 + X_2X1​+X2​?

Yup that's correct! The comonad structure comes from the fact that Z[X]\mathbb{Z}[X]Z[X] is a comonoid in CRING\mathsf{CRING}CRING with respect to ⊗\otimes⊗
(which is just a fancy way of saying that Z[X]\mathbb{Z}[X]Z[X] is a bialgebra)

John Baez said:

(In other notation X1+X2X_1 + X_2X1​+X2​ is X⊗1+1⊗X∈A[X]⊗AA[X]X \otimes 1 + 1 \otimes X \in A[X] \otimes_A A[X]X⊗1+1⊗X∈A[X]⊗A​A[X], which is a respectable-looking thing for a comultiplication to do.)

Yes this is the canonical comultiplication of the polynomial ring, which makes it a bialgebra (and also a Hopf algebra)

So if CALGA\mathsf{CALG}_ACALGA​ is the category of commutative AAA-algebras. In this category, ⊗A\otimes_A⊗A​ is the coproduct. What this identity is saying is that PP(A)PP(A)PP(A) is the coproduct of P(A)P(A)P(A) and P(A)P(A)P(A) in CALGA\mathsf{CALG}_ACALGA​

Hugo Jenkins said:

If C\mathcal{C}C is the category of unital commutative rings, we can consider the endofunctor A↦A[X]A\mapsto A[X]A↦A[X]. It outputs the ``free AAA-algebra''.

How should I think about the interactions of this endofunctor with tensor product? Such as:

  • A[X]⊗AA[X]≅A[X,Y]A[X]\otimes_A A[X]\cong A[X,Y]A[X]⊗A​A[X]≅A[X,Y]
  • If A→ιBA\overset{\iota}{\to} BA→ιB, then A[X]/I⊗AB≅B[X]/Bι(I)A[X]/I \otimes_A B \cong B[X]/B\iota(I)A[X]/I⊗A​B≅B[X]/Bι(I).

The first isomorphism is an example of the Seely isomorphism of linear logic/differential categories. But maybe the answer without differential categories is simpler depending of your definition of simple.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

The first isomorphism is an example of the Seely isomorphism of linear logic/differential categories.

No this is a bit misleading... The question was about the question the endofunctor on the category of CRING\mathsf{CRING}CRING. So it is not the so called Seely isomorphism in this case.

To @Jean-Baptiste Vienney point, if you consider the endofunctor on MODA\mathsf{MOD}_AMODA​, the category of AAA-modules, SA:MODA→MODAS_A: \mathsf{MOD}_A \to \mathsf{MOD}_ASA​:MODA​→MODA​ which maps an AAA-module MMM to the free commutative AAA-algebra over MMM, SA(M)S_A(M)SA​(M), then yes that is that first identity is the Seely isomorphism, which in general is SA(M×N)≅SA(M)⊗ASA(N)S_A(M \times N) \cong S_A(M) \otimes_A S_A(N)SA​(M×N)≅SA​(M)⊗A​SA​(N). And for the particular case you are thinking about:
SA(A)=A[X]S_A(A) = A[X]SA​(A)=A[X] and SA(A×A)≅A[X,Y]S_A(A \times A) \cong A[X,Y]SA​(A×A)≅A[X,Y]
so SA(A)⊗ASA(A)≅SA(A×A)S_A(A) \otimes_A S_A(A) \cong S_A(A \times A)SA​(A)⊗A​SA​(A)≅SA​(A×A)

But @Hugo Jenkins question was not about this. It was about the endofunctor P:CRING→CRINGP: \mathsf{CRING} \to \mathsf{CRING}P:CRING→CRING, mapping a commutative ring AAA to the polynomial ring in one variable A[X]A[X]A[X], so P(A)=SA(A)P(A) = S_A(A)P(A)=SA​(A). Which is different than the functor SA:MODA→MODAS_A: \mathsf{MOD}_A \to \mathsf{MOD}_ASA​:MODA​→MODA​.

I appreciate your enthusiasm for differential categories and answering questions, and trying to link things back to them. But I disagree with your answer of using Seely isomorphisms and differential categories to answer this question.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

But maybe the answer without differential categories is simpler depending of your definition of simple.

This isn't a very useful comment. I mean, for anyone who does not work with differential categories: usually answering questions without differential categories is always going to be simpler and more useful for them rather than throwing the words differential categories and Seely isomorphisms at them.
Be nice.

Yup that's correct! The comonad structure comes from the fact that Z[X]\mathbb{Z}[X]Z[X] is a comonoid in CRING\mathsf{CRING}CRING with respect to ⊗\otimes⊗
(which is just a fancy way of saying that Z[X]\mathbb{Z}[X]Z[X] is a bialgebra)

Perhaps the fact I was looking for is just that the functor PPP is equal to −⊗Z[x]-\otimes \mathbb{Z[x]}−⊗Z[x]. What is the universal property of Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] with respect to CRING,⊗\mathsf{CRING}, \otimesCRING,⊗?

Does PPP being −⊗Z[x]-\otimes \mathbb{Z}[x]−⊗Z[x] explain the evaluation map/universal property of A[x]A[x]A[x]? (I.e. that a map A→BA\to BA→B extends uniquely to A[x]→BA[x]\to BA[x]→B sending xxx to any prescribed element)?

for CRing \mathbf{CRing} CRing, ⊗ \otimes ⊗ is the coproduct, and the free ring on a set of elements (the corresponding polynomial ring Z[S] \mathbb{Z}[S] Z[S]) is a left adjoint, so we get coproduct preservation. You can probably derive everything from just this.
the universal property of Z[x] \mathbb{Z}[x] Z[x] is really just the commutative ring generated from one element, no need to put ⊗ \otimes ⊗ in the picture yet
